text: Out of curiosity, is anyone experimenting or seeing success with using custom Google structured data on HS sites? I know HubSpot is doing AMP natively, but didn't know if anyone had messed around with different content types

you’re meaning structured data as in adding the schema tags/attributes n whatnot right?

I’ve done that in the past, but not much on HubSpot, few of the HS sites I work on would get much benefit from them, they’re either large enough that Google already has the data and displays it, or it’s not worth the extra time to the client

right, as described here:
<https://developers.google.com/search/docs/guides/search-features>

I agree most sites I work on aren't directly applicable either, but hey, if there's a prominent SERP spot with lower competition, I'm willing to experiment a bit lol. Again, I'm asking mainly out of curiosity.

What I can say from past experience is that it’s generally always better to give search engines as much information as possible, and structured data is a great way to do that. - it can also cause them to update the search results to show call to actions like phone call buttons and stuff like that.

Unfortunately I don’t have any statistics on if having those additional things show up in search had any actual effect on click through rate, and don’t have actual stats on how it affected ranking, but I do know it did help me rank some sites higher.

yeah, I had a call with some of the AMP team at HS a week or so ago and was telling them how that one box was like a SEO magic pill for us lol. almost all our mobile traffic went to those versions instead. didn't know if doubling down on Google-friendly content would amplify (pun not intended) those results

yea, I would say - as long as it’s done right, it can’t hurt - it can only improve things. so it’s like - if there’s a chance it can improve your ranking, and there’s no real con to it, is it worth it? probably
Especially with the new advancements in AI from Google i would say the more the merrier
Getting email address from URL and passing through an embedded HubSpot form. Anyone have a quick and tested solution before I start down this path?

If they come from a url to the page, let’s say its <http://google.com/page?email=email@email.com|google.com/page?email=email@email.com>
The form on <http://google.com/page|google.com/page> will autofill the form on that page?
At least that is how it works on the cms
I think that works on external forms too
